Award.AwardTitle: Critical Tests Of Stellar Evolution Theory
Award.AbstractNarration:
The principal investigator will accurately measure the global properties of stars, like their mass, size, brightness, temperature, and composition. He will use these measurements to improve the ability of computer models to predict stellar properties at various stages in their life cycles. Such models are the foundation of our understanding of how our Milky Way Galaxy and its member stars (including our Sun) reached their present state. They also tell us about the timescale for planet formation, which has a significant impact on how well we understand the origin of planets like our own. Despite advances in recent decades, stellar models still show some significant disagreements with observations. The measurements obtained by this project will help to improve stellar physics, and it will offer valuable opportunities to engage students in all aspects of scientific research, providing support for two summer undergraduate students each year.

The project will measure the fundamental properties of carefully-selected target stars in eclipsing or astrometric binary systems, which will provide the strongest constraints on theory. The sample includes low-mass stars, which have been shown to often be larger and cooler than predicted by models, for reasons that are still unclear. The main goal is to obtain highly accurate measurements of the absolute masses, radii, effective temperatures, luminosities, chemical composition, and other properties of the components, aiming at relative precisions of 1-2% in the masses and radii. The observational component of the project will include photometric light curves, high-resolution spectra, and long-baseline interferometry. Specific aspects of theory that will be tested include convection (mixing length approximation, overshooting), tidal effects that lead to rotational synchronization and orbital circularization, and the effects of magnetic activity and spots on the absolute stellar properties.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A main objective of this project has been to obtain highly accurate measurements of the basic properties of stars of different kinds, ranging from the youngest ones that were born only a few million years ago to others that are billions of years older than our own Sun. The goal has been to use these measurements as constraints to guide the work of theorists who develop models of how a star evolves with time. Having good models is important because by comparing the observed properties of stars with predictions from theory we can infer other properties that are not directly observable, such as the age. The project has yielded state-of-the-art measurements of stellar masses (the most fundamental property of a star), stellar sizes, temperatures, luminosities, distances, and chemical compositions, often with precisions of 1% or better. These results have aided our understanding of stellar physics, and in particular they have cast light on long-standing discrepancies in the predictions of current models of stellar evolution for the smallest stars, which are only half the size of the Sun, or smaller. Such stars are observed to be larger and cooler than expected from models, possibly due to strong magnetic activity. They are of special interest because they are commonly found to host Earth-like planets that in some cases may even be habitable. It is therefore important to understand the physics of these stars as well as possible in order to infer better properties for their planets.

Another of the key outcomes of the project has to do with the internal structure of stars. We know that all stars burn hydrogen in their cores by transforming it into helium, which is the process that fuels their luminosity. The exact size of the hydrogen-burning core and how it depends on the mass of the star is not well known from first principles. A large sample of carefully selected binary stars with well-measured properties was used in this project to infer the size of the core, and examine its dependence on stellar mass. This resulted in the first robust empirical calibration of such a dependence, which has considerable impact for the determination of ages of stars. This new calibration has already been incorporated by another team of theorists into at least one set of current models of stellar evolution.

Other results obtained during this award include the accurate measurement of properties of stars that are so young that they are still collapsing from the natal molecular clouds in which they formed, and have not yet reached the point at which they begin burning hydrogen in their cores. These objects are especially important for constraining and improving models at the earliest stages of stellar evolution.

The efforts described above resulted in the publication of a total of 29 papers in peer-reviewed journals over the life of the award.

Finally, the project has also offered valuable opportunities for mentoring in science, providing experience to several students (including minorities) in scientific research, in communicating results to peers through active participation in the preparation of peer-reviewed publications and presentations at scientific meetings, and in the application of established professional norms and ethical principles of the performance of these activities.
